qas.question: What percentage of people in Burma are related by linguistically lines to the Khmer.

answers.text: 2% of the population, are ethno-linguistically related to the Khmer

qas.question: Which community previously held a persuasive authority on the Burmese population?
When did a mass migration of the community that  previously held a persuasive authority on the Burmese population start?
Where did the majority of these people end up after Burma ?

answers.text: principally to Australia and the UK

context: Mon, who form <a0_0>2% of the population, are ethno-linguistically related to the Khmer<a0_0/>. Overseas Indians are 2%. The remainder are Kachin, Chin, Rohingya, Anglo-Indians, Gurkha, Nepali and other ethnic minorities. Included in this group are the <a1_0>Anglo-Burmese<a1_0/>. Once forming a large and influential community, the Anglo-Burmese left the country in steady streams from <a2_0>1958 onwards<a2_0/>, <a3_0>principally to Australia and the UK<a3_0/>. It is estimated that 52,000 Anglo-Burmese remain in Myanmar. As of 2009[update], 110,000 Burmese refugees were living in refugee camps in Thailand.
